comment.name: UmaSofia Srivastava
comment.comment info:
Overall, electricity generation has increased over time. While the use of clean energy sources globally has grown over the last 20 years, the use of fossil fuels has been consistently higher. Coal and gas are the most popular sources, and wind/solar power has experienced the most growth recently. 

I wonder why, even with the proliferation of new ways to generate electricity, the use of gas and coal has steadily increased. It must have something to do with the accessibility of the resources, but I wonder how much the growth of global population effects how electricity is generated. I wonder how greatly these statistics vary from country to country. 

Canvassing for the local democratic campaign, I noticed that clean energy was a very important issue. Everyone is impacted by the negative effects brought about by climate change, which the expenditure of fossil fuels has been proven to greatly contribute to global warming. 

Good Ole’ Coal: It’s Electric!

comment.name: Nathan
comment.comment info:
We evaluated a 2022 graph titled “World electricity generation” by Ember. We noticed that it displayed the types and amounts of energy used throughout the world as a whole from 2000 to the 2020s. There were also separate graphs that specifically documented the energy usage of the United States, China, and India over the same time period. We noted that the overall energy usage worldwide for all types is going up, and that nuclear is the most prominent energy source while coal is the least prominent. We also noticed that there were “dips” in worldwide energy usage around 2008 and 2020, which probably correspond with the economic hardships caused by the 2008 housing crisis and the coronavirus pandemic. 

 

We wonder what the data looked like before 2000, as “clean” energy seems to be a relatively new phenomenon. We also wonder why India’s energy usage is so low when compared to the United States and China.

 

This topic is important because we all use energy every day, and it is useful to know the main types of energy being used. It also gives more insight into how different countries operate.

 

Our title for the graph is “Ember’s Evaluation of the Evolution of Electricity.”

comment.name: Matt Ferreira
comment.comment info:
All types of electricity generation have been on the rise in terms of total electricity produces since the year 2000. Of the forms of electricity generation, clean energy produces the most, with nuclear and hydroelectric electricity taking the #1 and #2 spots. Among fossil fuels, oil and gas produce the most electricity, but not nearly as much as clean forms of energy such as in nuclear or hydroelectric forms. 

I wonder how the total electricity generated for each form of generation depends on the energy production of each country. China seems to be on the rise and most likely will still continue generating more and more electricity, with a high emphasis on fossil fuels. The USA has remained rather constant, and is interesting because there seems to be a downtrend in fossil fuels. Could this be because they source fossil fuels from other countries?

I live in the USA, and so the graph showing the forms of electrical generation in the US is interesting to me. It shows that gas has been becoming the main source of electrical power for the US, as well as coal. Clean forms of energy generation like solar power have only contributed a speck to the total energy production, despite it being made a huge deal nowadays.

Headline:
Energy Evolution: Transitioning from Fossil Fuels to Clean Sources

comment.name: Jackson Woodward
comment.comment info: This graph charts the source of the world’s electricity supply based on the method of its production--that is, whether the electricity was produced via fossil fuel consumption in the form of oil, gas, and coal; or, if clean sources like hydroelectric, wind, solar, and nuclear power were used in production. The lion’s share of global power production, as the graph indicates, originates in the burning of coal, and, more broadly, other fossil fuels. This is despite an evident recent uptick in reliance on clean energy sources, perhaps spurred on by recent ecocentric movements and such measures as the Paris Accords. Indeed, the pressures to which such a move responds seem pressing, so much so that the global predominance of coal energy sources--which produce the greatest amount of and therefore most harmful greenhouse emissions--incites no little concern. This concerning trend finds further grounding in the subsequent graphs included below, wherein the global energy consumption is broken apart into a few constituent countries’. The graph evinces that China, one of the world’s foremost economic and industrial superpowers, remains largely dependent on coal energy for its massive energy consumption, around twice that of the United States. The unfortunate truth of such statistics is that overreliance on coal does not only affect the country producing it, but has devastating environmental ramifications for the entire world.

comment.name: Alex Tran
comment.comment info: First examining the “World electricity generation” graph demonstrates an evident increase in electricity generation with fossil fuels dominating a majority of the sources of that energy. Of the clean energy, it’s interesting to note that hydroelectric and other is the greatest source of clean energy compared to nuclear and wind/solar. Of the fossil fuels, coal is the greatest source of fossil fuels compared to gas and oil (and other). Another intriguing thing to note is that clean energy seems to be increasing faster than fossil fuels, however, with clean energy sources taking a bigger share of the total world electricity generation as time passes. I wonder how this increase in clean energy will affect the countries’ totals since China seems to follow that trend of clean energy’s greater share of the world total, but the United States’s and India’s totals seem to be changing at slower rates than China’s. With the rise of clean energy, I hope that statistics like these cause us to reflect on how our communities and we use electricity and where our electricity is coming from. I strongly hope there are more talks especially regarding sustainability when it comes to unrenewable sources of energy such as fossil fuels. A catchy headline could be “Our Energy Sources are Electrifying the World - 2000 to 2022”

comment.name: Warren Woo
comment.comment info:
The first thing I noticed was that the United States' energy usage was only about twice as less as China's usage despite having a population less than a quarter the size of China's. This means that the average energy usage per person in the US is significantly greater than China's and especially India's. I then noticed the change in the type of energy the United States' has used over the years. From 2000 to 2020 there seems to be a decrease in coal, an small but noticeable increase in wind and solar, and then an increase in oil. So while the increased use of the clean wind and solar energy, and the decrease of coal energy looks good, I wonder if it is offset by the dramatic increase in oil. 
As the graph depicts energy usage from 2000 to 2020, I am able to observe if me and my family's energy usage coorelates with the graph. Over the last 20 years many families in my neighborhood, including my own, added solar panels to their roofs, this lines up fairly accurately with when solar and wind power starts to increase (around 2010). I am glad to see this change, however I unfortunately also observe that with the layout of my suburban town, driving is almost essential to go to places so seeing an increase in oil also makes sense. These graphs should encourage people to cut out oil, if they need to go somewhere close and walking/biking is a feasible means of travel then they should consider that instead. My title: "3 largest countries in the world, and how they consume energy"

The graph shows the world electricity generation from the year 2000 to just beyond 2020, with sources split into "clean" and "fossil". comment.name: Jena Weitzman
comment.comment info:
In this graph, I notice that there is an overall increase in the trend of world electricity generation, when looking at all sources of electricity. In differentiating between clean sources and fossil fuels, clean sources seem to be much more prevalent in use than fossil fuels, which is a positive consequence. Diving even further into detail, I noticed that the United States has a much more gradual increase in electricity generation than that of China, which has a much steeper slope and more rapid increase in electricity generation.
I wonder why exactly China's electricity generation has increased so much faster than that of the United States. Both China and the United States are massive centers of economic and industrial growth, so it is interesting that China's change in electricity generation is far more drastic than the United States.
Energy sources have a huge impact on me and my surrounding community. It is highly important that we steer away from using fossil fuels as an energy source, as they are detrimental to the environment and the world that we live in, and create more sources of clean energy. The United States' electricity generation increasing at a much slower rate is both good and bad for my community- good in the sense that less fossil fuels are being used, bad in the sense that less clean energy is used. I would title this graph "Fueling the Future- World Electricity Generation from 2000 to 2020".

comment.name: Gabby
comment.comment info:
What do you notice?
-Over the years, China had the steepest increase in electricity generation, for all types of power, compared to the United States and India. 
- In 2000, China had lower amounts of electricity generation than the US but surpassed the US by around 2010. 
- The overall electricity generation in the US has not increased by much over the years, but there is a larger proportion of clean fuels being used instead of fossil fuels (especially coal).
- India’s electricity generation remained lower than both China and the US but has steadily increased over the years. 

What do you wonder?
- I wonder if the increase in electricity generation in China is correlated with how “open” their economy was. I know that China has worked on expanding its private sector. 
- I wonder why US electricity generation has plateaued, and if this phenomenon is also seen in other Western developed countries. 
- What is the relationship between energy generation and the political stability of a country?

How does this relate to you and your community?
- This relates to how I might think/vote about certain energy policies in the US. 
- I see a lot more Teslas in the Bay Area - electric cars don’t seem like they are reserved for the rich anymore; many middle-class folks are buying Teslas to account for rising gas prices.

Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
Our Energy Usage Has Transformed Over the Last 20 Years

comment.comment info:
I noticed that worldwide clean electricity sources such as nuclear, wind, solar, and hydroelectric have experienced a greater increase in output of electricity over time compared to fossil fuels. Meanwhile, the United States’ coal usage is the only source that experienced a decrease in generation. 
I am curious as to why the US is less reliant on coal, if it has something to do with the cost of mining coal, or if the US is choosing to prioritize investing in clean sources instead. If the US is in fact choosing to spend more on clean sources of electricity this would mean, policymakers are becoming more conscious of the need to take steps to protect the environment so our planet can be habitable for the next generation. I would title this graph: “Electricity Generation for our Next Generation”.

comment.name: Amy Truong
comment.comment info: After examining the World’s Electricity Generation Graph, I noticed that clean sources produce the most amount of power in the world compared to fossil fuels. More specifically, nuclear sources produce the most overall. Additionally, as the years increase, more and more electricity is being produced from all sources. In the smaller graphs below, I notice that China uses by far the most electricity compared to the United States and India. India produces the least amount of electricity and also uses the least amount of clean energy sources to produce electricity. I wonder if there is a reason as to why India produces the least amount of electricity. India is a very large country with over a billion people, so based on that, I would assume that India would be one of the countries that produces the most amount of electricity. The impact that this has on me and my community is making me wonder how much electricity I use daily and what kind of energy sources produce my electricity. Although, when observing the United States graph I notice that as the years increase, fossil fuel usage decreases. I am pointing this out because based on this observation, the electricity I use is more likely to be powered by clean energy sources. After looking at the main graph and the sub-graphs of the other countries, a catchy “headline” that captures these graphs is “How Different Powers Charge the World”.

comment.name: Jordan
comment.comment info:
I notice that the United States' electricity generation has barely raised at all since 2000 (with gas and wind/solar power taking much of the share from coal), while the world's total generation has raised by well over 10 million gigawatt hours (GWh). China's generation alone accounts for about 8 million GWh, with India accounting for about 1 million GWh. Furthermore, we see that worldwide nuclear generation has barely moved at all, while hydroelectric looks like it's about doubled. Wind and solar has gone from no generation to about 3 million GWh, gas looks like it's about doubled from 3 to 6 million GWh, and coal has risen from 5 to about 8 million GWh.

I wonder why China's generation has increased so much while the United States remained so similar. China has certainly been developing, but more than quintupling their electricity generation seems absurd. What were they doing before they were generating it themselves? Were they importing all of it? I also wonder why no new nuclear energy is being produced when we know how safe and reliable it is.

As the world looks to move towards renewable energy, we see that fossil fuel consumption is still only increasing worldwide. With climate change impacting the world more and more, we are seeing more extreme weather like the polar vortexes that sweep across the US in winter, plunging the Midwest into wind chills below -40 degrees Fahrenheit.

"Electricity Generation in China Soars to More Than Double the United States"

comment.name: Clare
comment.comment info:
These graphs show total energy generation by country but the text says they exclude imports and exports so they probably don't represent usage by that country. If any of these countries are net importers of energy then their total consumption would be higher, whereas if they're net exporters it then it would be lower.

Coal and gas still by far make up the largest part of the market however wind and solar production is increasing at the fastest rate. Nuclear and other seam to have slightly reduced in production and hydro slightly increased.

There are two dips in production at around 2008 and 2019 (less pronounced in coal). I wonder what caused them. Something to do with the GFC and COVID19?

In terms of country level, China is by far producing the most coal and its coal production has increased around 4 times since 2000 and it looks to be the biggest coal producer in the world.

In the US by comparison, coal production has decreased by more than half and oil has increased. Oil and gas combined has stayed fairly steady and still make up more than half of overall production. Overall US energy production has stayed fairly steady over the 22 years.  

India does not produce very much energy at all compared to the other countries and it is mostly coal.
